caption: Table 1: Comparison with multi-modal narrative datasets. Most existing datasets focus on image-based comic story generation. In contrast, our dataset consists of long narrative videos, containing 150×\times× the number of frames and 5×\times× the dense text annotations compared to the previous largest dataset, StoryStream.
description: Table 1 compares CookGen with other multi-modal narrative datasets.  Unlike most existing datasets, which focus on image-based comic stories, CookGen uses long-form videos.  It contains significantly more data: 150 times the number of frames and 5 times the amount of text annotation data as StoryStream, the previously largest dataset of this type.

caption: Table 2: Long narrative dataset sources. Our dataset is built upon Youcook2 and a cooking subset of Howto100M.
description: This table details the composition of the CookGen dataset used in the study.  It shows that the dataset was created by combining data from two existing sources: YouCook2 and a subset of HowTo100M, both of which contain cooking videos. The table specifies the number of videos, clips, average clip length, and clips per video in both the training and validation sets of CookGen, providing a quantitative overview of the dataset's size and structure.

content:
Validation Set w/. GT keyframe W/o. GT keyframe
# Clips FVD FVD
5504 116.3 561.1
caption: Table 3: Inverse video generation. Evaluation of caption quality through inverse video generation with and without keyframes. FVD scores reflect reasonable video reconstruction quality.
description: This table presents the results of an experiment evaluating the quality of video captions generated by the model using an inverse video generation method.  The experiment compares the quality of video reconstruction when using captions alone versus using captions combined with ground truth keyframes. The Fréchet Video Distance (FVD) score, a metric for evaluating the quality of generated videos, is used to measure the similarity between the reconstructed videos and the original videos. Lower FVD scores indicate higher reconstruction quality and a better ability of the captions to represent the original video.

content:
GPT-4o Evaluation Human Evaluation
Score (0-100) Qwen2-VL-72B Ours Qwen2-VL-72B Ours
98.0 95.2 79.3 82.0
caption: Table 4: Caption Quality Evaluation. We compare the caption quality between our captioner and the Qwen2-VL-72B model by both GPT-4o and human annotators. Our model achieves competitive results despite a much smaller model size.
description: This table presents a comparison of caption quality between the authors' model and the Qwen2-VL-72B model.  The evaluation is performed using both GPT-4 and human annotators, assessing aspects like coverage of video elements and the absence of hallucinations. Notably, the authors' model achieves comparable performance to Qwen2-VL-72B despite having a significantly smaller model size.

content:
Method Autoencoder Style VL Aligned. Recon. Ability CLIP-T FID
SDXL-VAE Variational U-Net ✗ High 13.2 286.6
EMU-2 CLIP-Diffusion ✓ Medium 25.4 76.7
SEED-X CLIP-Diffusion ✓ Low 25.1 30.1
caption: Table 5: Visual latent spaces for visual regression. The VAE latent space is challenging for auto-regressive models to regress in a single step due to its limited correlation with language. In contrast, the language-aligned latent spaces (EMU-2 and SEED-X) allow for easier and effective regression in an interleaved manner.
description: This table compares the performance of different visual latent spaces used in visual regression for autoregressive models.  The results show that Variational Autoencoders (VAEs), due to their weak correlation with language, are difficult for these models to regress in a single step.  In contrast, language-aligned spaces like those from EMU-2 and SEED-X models facilitate easier and more effective regression when used in an interleaved manner.

Loss Type Training Validation Training Validation
MSE Cos. L2 Dist. Cosine. CLIP FID L2 Dist. Cosine. CLIP FID
✓ ✗ 0.41 0.82 23.6 31.9 1.3 0.78 25.1 80.1
✗ ✓ 1.1 0.82 24.1 32.1 2.5 0.79 23.5 115.3
✓ ✓ 0.41 0.83 25.1 30.1 1.4 0.79 25.4 76.7
caption: Table 6: Regression loss with scale and direction. We track the training convergence and evaluate models with the CLIP-T and FID metrics on the validation set. Both Seed-X and EMU-2 latent space show that a combination of both MSE loss and Cosine Similarity loss considering both scale and direction performs best. SEED-X and EMU-2 original regression loss setting is grayed.
description: This table presents an ablation study on the impact of different regression loss functions on the quality of visual embeddings generated by the interleaved auto-regressive model.  Specifically, it investigates the effects of using Mean Squared Error (MSE) loss, Cosine Similarity loss, and combinations thereof. The results are evaluated using CLIP-T and Fréchet Inception Distance (FID) scores on a validation set. The table shows that a combination of MSE and Cosine Similarity loss yields the best performance, suggesting the importance of considering both the scale and direction of the visual embeddings during regression.

content:
Training Validation
Regression Task L2 Dist. Cosine Sim. CLIP-T FID
Action →→\rightarrow→ Vis. Embed. 0.43 0.82 22.7 27.9
Caption →→\rightarrow→ Vis. Embed. 0.41 0.82 25.7 26.1
Action →→\rightarrow→ Caption →→\rightarrow→ Vis. Embed. 0.41 0.83 26.1 25.3
caption: Table 7: From “Actions” to “Visual States”. We report the L2 distance and cosine similarity scores for tracking the training convergence and evaluate the generation images with CLIP score and FID score. Models are trained and evaluated on the collected Howto100M subset. SEED-X latent is used for visual regression.
description: This table presents the results of an experiment evaluating different approaches to generating visual states in a long narrative video generation model.  It compares three different strategies for transitioning from actions to visual states: (1) Action -> Visual Embedding, (2) Action -> Caption -> Visual Embedding, and (3) Action -> Caption -> Visual Embedding. The evaluation metrics include L2 distance and cosine similarity to track training convergence, and CLIP score and FID score to assess the quality of the generated images.  All models were trained and evaluated using the HowTo100M dataset subset and SEED-X latent space for visual regression.

Latent condition Gen. strategy Aesthetic Realistic Visual consist. Narrative
EMU-2 Latent Interleaved 0.7 1.2 2.9 2.2
SEED-X Latent Interleaved 2.1 4.3 4.5 4.4
Text (SDXL) Language-centric 4.0 2.9 3.3 4.0
Text (FLUX.1-s) Language-centric 4.8 3.1 3.4 4.4
caption: Table 8: Human Evaluation – Interleaved vs. Language-centric. This table compares different latent conditioning and generation strategies based on semantic alignment, aesthetic quality, visual consistency, and narrative coherence. Each aspect is scored with five tiers: 1∼similar-to\sim∼5, score higher is better.
description: Table 8 compares the performance of two approaches to video generation: interleaved and language-centric.  The comparison is based on four key aspects: semantic alignment (how well the generated content aligns with the intended meaning), aesthetic quality (the visual appeal of the generated video), visual consistency (how well the video maintains visual style throughout), and narrative coherence (how well the story unfolds logically). Each aspect is rated on a scale of 1 to 5, with 5 being the highest score.  This allows for a quantitative comparison of the two methods' strengths and weaknesses across multiple dimensions of video quality.

content:
Visual Condition YouCook2 HowTo100M
CLIP-T FVD CLIP-T FVD
Keyframe 25.9 557.7 26.6 541.1
Embedding 26.4 512.6 27.3 520.7
caption: Table 9: Keyframes vs. Visual Embeddings. Evaluate CLIP-T and FVD scores for video generation conditioned on keyframes versus visual embeddings generated by our interleaved director.
description: This table compares the performance of video generation when conditioned on keyframes versus visual embeddings generated by the model's interleaved director.  Specifically, it evaluates the quality of the generated videos using two metrics: CLIP-T, a metric assessing the semantic similarity between the generated video and the reference text, and FVD (Fréchet Video Distance), a metric measuring the visual similarity.  The comparison shows the impact of using the model's generated visual embeddings, which aim to be more semantically aligned with the textual narrative, instead of relying solely on static keyframes.

content:
Matching Tier Action (Important Info.) Object (Important Info.) Score
Very Match Good Coverage, No Hallucination Good Coverage, No Hallucination 100
Good Match Good Coverage, Limited Hallucination Good Coverage, Limited Hallucination 85
Somehow Match Fair Coverage, Some Hallucination Fair Coverage, Some Hallucination 70
Not Match Little Coverage or High Hallucination Little Coverage or High Hallucination 0
caption: Table 10: Human Evaluation Matching Rules. Captions are rated based on coverage and hallucination levels, using four matching tiers.
description: This table details the criteria used for human evaluation of video captioning quality.  Evaluators assess captions based on two key aspects: (1) how well the caption covers important information from the video and (2) the presence or absence of hallucination (i.e., the caption generating details not present in the video).  Four matching tiers (Very Match, Good Match, Somehow Match, and Not Match) categorize the quality based on coverage and hallucination levels, with scores assigned accordingly.
